name: ʿAbd al-Masīḥ b. Maqāra b. Hārūn
description: Christian physician who bought a slavewoman from Sitt al-Munā bt. Natan/Hibatallāh, the widow of Nahray b. Nissim.

name: Abū al-Faḍl al-Ṣayrafī Maṣliah b. Meshullam
(Abū ʿAlī) Muḥsin b. Ḥusayn
name_variants: אבו עלי מחסן בן חסין, ابو علي محسن بن حسين
description: representative of the merchants in Fustat; parnas of the Palestinian Rabbanite community in Fustat; descended from a Rabbanite trading family from the northern Syrian coast (Rustow, Heresy, 225)

name: Abū ʿImrān Moshe ha-Kohen Tifʾeret ha-Kohanim
Abū l-Faḍl b. Barakāt b. al-Maqdisī
description: Silk weaver, had four sons.

name: Abū Zikrī Kohen
name_variants: Abū Zikrī Yehuda b. Yosef ha-Kohen al-Sijilmāsī
description: Representative of the merchants (wakīl al-tujjār) in Fustat in the 1120s and 1130s and an Indian Ocean trader. Originally from Sijilmāsa.

name: Aharon b. Yeshuʿa ha-Rofeʾ Ibn al-ʿAmmānī
Al-Afḍal b. Badr al-Jamālī
description: Al-Afḍal b. Badr al-Jamālī (d. 1121), was the Fatimid chief wazīr and commander of forces (amīr al-Juyūsh). He was the son of Badr al-Jamālī (d. 1094), the Fatimid wazīr and army commander, and was in office from 1094–1121.

name: Amīr Fakhr al-Dīn Abū Manṣūr ʿIzz al-ʿArab b. Muḥammad
description: State official active around 1170s in the late Fatimid period. He was a bureaucrat serving under al-Ḥāfiẓ and al-Ẓāfir. In one of the documents, he is sanctioned a medical treatise from the royal library "khizānat al-kutub" of al-Ḥāfiẓ. He is portrayed as a good state official, often intervening on behalf of the dhimmīs for affairs related to the capitation tax.

name: Ammār b. Ezrūn al-Madīnī
description: According to Gil he died in the summer of 1062.

name: ʿAmram b. Ezra
name_variants: עמרם הזקן השלחני בר עזרא ראש הקהל אלאסכנדראני

name: ʿAṭāʾ b. Isḥāq b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Avraham b. Yijū
description: Placeholder

name: Badr al-Jamālī
description: Fatimid chief wazir and army commander who served under al-Mustanṣir (d. 1094) from 1073-1094. Originally an Armenian and a convert to Islam, he was initially deployed in Acre before he arrived in Egypt in 1073.

name: Barhūn b. Isḥāq b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Barhūn b. Ismāʿīl b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Barhūn b. Mūsā b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Barhūn b. Ṣāliḥ b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Binyām
description: A druggist of Rosetta (Rashīd) active in the early to mid-12th century.

name: Dāwūd b. Ammār b. Ezrūn al-Madīnī
Efrayim b. Shemarya
name_variants: (Abū Kathīr) Efrayim b. Shemarya, אפרים החבר ברבי שמריה
description: Head of the congregation of the Shāmīs in Fustat (the one based in the synagogue later called the Ben Ezra). Floruit ca. 1007–1055.

name: Elḥanan b. Ismāʿīl b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Elḥanan b. Shemarya
description: Placeholder

name: Fakhr al-Dawla
description: Ayyubid state official with some connection to Abraham Maimonides. There are at least 12 documents that mention him.

name: Faraḥ b. Yַūsuf b. Faraḥ al-Qābisī
Fāris al-Dawla
description: The amīr Fāris al-Dawla was active in the 6th/12th century during the period of al-Fāʾiz.

name: Farjūn
description: The most popular man in the geniza. ;-)

name: Ghālib b. Moshe ha-Kohen
name_variants: Abū Naṣr Ghālib b. Moshe ha-Kohen, Abū Naṣr ha-Kohen Ghālib b. Moshe

name: Ḥalfon ha-Levi b. Netanʾel
description: India trader [placeholder]

name: Ḥamīd al-Dawla
description: Fatimid state official, 11th/12th C.

name: Ḥananya b. Yosef ha-Kohen, Av Bet Din
name_variants: Ḥananya Av Bet Din b. Yosef Ga'on
description: Active first decades of the eleventh century (legal document from his court precisely dated to 1007)

name: Hayye bar Sherira
description: Gaʾon of the yeshiva of Pumbedita in Baghdad 998–1038. Born in 939. Author of numerous responsa and legal monographs in Judaeo-Arabic, as well as a commentary on the Mishnah.  Two of Hayye's monographs spread widely in the Middle Ages and were translated into Hebrew more than once: Kitāb al-Aymān, on judicial oaths; and Kitāb al-Shirāʾ wa ʾl-Bayʿ, on the laws of sale. Before serving as gaʾon, Hayye held the position of chief judge (Heb. av bet din) of the yeshiva of Pumbedita. According to Robert Brody (s.v. Hay (Hayya) Gaʾon in EJIW), Hayye was the only gaʾon to serve as his father’s immediate successor. The correct pronunciation of his name is Hayye (the Aramaic form of Ḥayyim), at least according to the rhyme-scheme of a poem published by Shelomo Morag in Tarbiẓ in 1962.

name: Hilāl al-Dawla
description: Fatimid state official, served under the administration of al-Āmir. He was sent as a diplomatic envoy and ambassador to the Sulayhid Empress Arwā bt. Aḥmad in Yemen with several gifts including robes that the caliph had worn, dried meat, copies of 12 sermons, and several other priced gifts. (Information from al-Maqrīzī, Ittiʿāẓ III, 103).

name: Ḥiyyā b. Yiṣḥaq
description: The head judge in Fusṭāṭ in the middle of the twelfth century. Active from 1129 until 1170. Author of several legal compositions. The son of the head judge Yiṣḥaq b. Shemu'el ha-Sepharadi.

name: Ḥusām al-Dawla
description: Fatimid state official, served under the administration of al-Mustanṣir.

name: Ibn al-Baʿbāʿ
name_variants: Abū Abdallāh, Abū ʿAbdallāh Muḥammad b. ʿAbd al-Raḥmān al-Ṣāʾigh
description: Ibn al-Baʿbāʿ was a Palermitan shipowner and merchant who had business ties with the Geniza merchants in the circle of Nahray b. Nissim, transporting their money, letters and other goods across the Mediterranean. Gil suggests his family were Jewish converts to Islam and perhaps came to Sicily from Andalusia. He was also the last known ruler of Muslim Palermo before the city surrendered to the Normans in 1072.

name: Ibn al-Thumna
description: Ibn al-Thumna was a qāʾid of Sicily in the mid-eleventh century. His base of operations was Catania and Syracuse but Geniza letters mention him in Palermo as well. After a losing battle with a rival qāʾid of Agrigento, Ibn al-Thumna turned to the Normans for help. Geoffrey Malaterra, the late eleventh-century Norman chronicler, describes Ibn al-Thumna's central role in the early years of the Norman conquest of Sicily. He was killed in 1062, a fact celebrated in one Geniza letter.

name: Iftikhār al-Dawla Mubārak al-Afḍalī al-Juyūshī
description: Fatimid state official, active around the 6th/12th C.

name: Ismaʿīl b. Yosef b. Abī ʿUqba
Karīma bt. ʿAmram (Wuḥsha al-Dallāla)
name_variants: Karīma bt. ʿAmmār, Karīma bt. ʿAmram, Wuḥsha al-Dallāla, וחשה אלדלאלה, כרימה בת עמאר, כרימה בת עמרם
description: Karima bt. ʿAmram/ʿAmmār is more commonly known by her nickname Wuḥsha al-Dallāla. She was a business woman of the late 11th/early 12th century in Fuṣtāṭ. She is one of the most well known women of this time period due to the survival of multiple documents capturing various aspects of her life. She was married to Arye b. Yehudah and had a daughter with him, Sitt al-Ḥasan. Her son, Abū Saʿd, was born out of wedlock after a relationship with Ḥassūn al-‘Asqalānī. For more on her life and business partnerships, see Goitein, "A Jewish Business Woman." RR

name: Maḍmūn b. Ḥasan
description: Representative of the merchants in Aden

name: Maḥrūz b. Yaʿaqov
description: Nākhudā (shipowner) traveling between Aden and India

name: Makhlūf b. Mūsā Ibn al-Yatīm
name_variants: Ibn ʿAynayn Shirra, Ibn ʿAynayn Sārra, Makhlūf al-Nafūsī, Makhlūf b. ʿAyn Sārra
description: Trader of the late eleventh and early twelfth century. An import-export merchant, he traveled between Iberia and India. Had legal disputes with Ibn Yijū in which he also tried to involve Maḍmūn b. Yūsuf. Ultimately, Maḍmūn paid Makhlūf 300 dinars on behalf of Ibn Yijū and Makhlūf dropped his claims.

name: Makīn al-Dawla
description: The amīr Thiqat al-Mulk Makīn al-Dawla was a state official during the period of the Fatimid caliph al-Ḥakim. Officials by the same title also existed in the periods of al-Mustanṣir and al-Āmir (see T-S 10J14.24, T-S 13J22.23).

name: Maṣliaḥ b. Eliyyahu
description: Judge of Palermo in the mid-eleventh century.

name: Maṣliaḥ b. Shelomo
description: Gaʾon of the Palestinian yeshiva in Cairo 1127–39.

name: Mūsā b. Yaḥyā al-Majjānī
description: Dates ca. 1000–1025

name: Nahray b. Nissim
description:
Nahray ben Nissim (ca. 1025-1098), nicknamed Abū Yaḥyā, was a North African merchant and communal leader. More than 350 letters, notes, and accounts from the Cairo Geniza are either addressed to him or emanate directly from his hand, comprising the largest corpus of documentary sources from the Geniza concerning a single individual.

Born around 1025 and descended from a leader (nagid) of the Qayrawan community, Nahray migrated to Egypt around 1040, where he entered the patronage of his relative Barhūn b. Isḥaq Tahertī. At the center of a network of traders plying the Mediterranean in the eleventh century, mostly of North African descent, Nahray was trusted and respected for his ability to determine the market value of commodities. After sojourning for a time in Alexandria, the center of flax commerce, he eventually settled in Fustat, though he regularly traveled throughout North Africa and visited Israel at least once. His commercial pursuits involved trade, money-changing, and debt collection by power of attorney.

Having studied at the Qayrawan academy of Nissim b. Jacob, Nahray was learned in rabbinic literature; he acted as a professional jurisconsult in Fustat and responded to queries from throughout North Africa. He also maintained ties to the Jerusalem academy and received two honorary titles therefrom. Nahray headed the congregation of "Babylonian" Jews in Fustat and even, for a time, also managed the affairs of the Palestinian synagogue. He supported the Palestinian nasi David ben Daniel in his conflict with Mevorakh ben Sa'adya between 1082 and 1094, but threw his support of the latter upon his restoration to the headship. In addition, Nahray interacted with officials of the Fāṭimid caliphate on behalf of members of the Rabbanite community and was a generous patron of the needy, ensuring that funds were paid to the heirs of those who perished in international commerce and acting as an agent for orphans. He also raised funds for the redemption of captives, in one case mobilizing the community to free Jewish merchants held by Byzantine forces in Amalfi. (From Phillip Ackerman-Lieberman, "Nahray ben Nissim" in Encyclopedia of Jews in the Islamic World)

name: Nissim b. Isḥāq b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Nissim b. Yaʿaqov
description: Head of the yeshiva at Qayrawān.

name: Riḍwān b. Walakhshī
description: Riḍwān b. al-Walakshī was a Fatimid wazīr and army commander under the caliph al-Ḥāfīẓ.

name: Saʿadya b. Avraham (Ibn al-Amshāṭī)
name_variants: Abū l-Fakhr, אבו אלפכר בר אברהם

name: Salāma b. Mūsā b. Yiṣḥaq al- Safāquṣī
Sar Shalom b. Moshe ha-Levi
description: Gaʾon

name: Shelomo b. Yehuda
name_variants: Shelomo Gaʾon b. Yehuda, Shelomo b. Yehuda (al-Fāsī), שלמה ברבי יהודה
description: Gaʾon of the Jerusalem yeshiva starting in fall 1025 until his death in 1051. Born ca. 970, either in Fez or to a family from Fez.

name: Shemarya b. Elḥanan
description: Placeholder

name: Shemuel b. Ḥananya
description: Nagid

name: Sherira bar Ḥananya
description: Gaʾon of the yeshiva of Pumbedita in Baghdad. Born ca. 906; rose to the gaonate in 968, and stepped down in 1004 when his son, Hayye, assumed the gaonate; queries continued to be addressed to Sherira and Hayye jointly. Author of numerous responsa, among them a now famous Iggeret penned in 986 in response to Yaʿaqov b. Nissim Ibn Shāhīn in Qayrawān about the composition of the Mishnah and other rabbinic literature and the history of the gaonate.

name: Surūra bt. Ṣāliḥ b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Tāj al-Dawla
description: State official, worked for the fiscal.

name: Yaʿaqov b. Nissim Ibn Shāhīn
description: Seriously famous. No person page, but I can't resist writing an entry anyway. Philosopher, mathematician, late 10th century; he's the guy who wrote the query that produced the Iggeret Sherira Gaʾon on the redaction of the Mishnah. Author of an Arabic commentary on the Sefer Yeṣirah. Hilariously harsh on the young Saʿadya: claims that when the latter was still in Egypt, he used to address very insignificant questions to Yiṣḥaq b. Shelomo of Qayrawān and comment on medical texts (Galen?) in such a way as to reveal that actually he didn't understand them. So he decided to write his own commentary on Galen, which is still extant. Also wrote a book on Indian mathematics called Ḥisāb al-Ghubār. Father of Rabbenu Nissim, author of a Talmud commentary and head of the yeshiva at Qayrawān. MR

name: Yaʿaqov b. Yosef b. ʿAwkal
description: Placeholder

name: Yedutun ha-Levi
name_variants: Abū l-Ḥasan b. Abū Sahl, Ḥasan b. Sahl
description: Cantor in the Palestinian synagogue in Fustat and prolific payyeṭan. Identified as a physician in two fragments. Associated with the party opposed to the liturgical reforms of Avraham Maimonides. Son of the cantor Abū Sahl Levi b. Ibrāhīm ha-Levi and brother of Moshe b. Levi ha-Levi.

name: Yehosef b. Yiṣḥaq b. Shemu'el ha-Sepharadi
description: The son of judge Yiṣḥaq b. Shemu'el ha-Sepharadi. Signed a few court deeds during the first half of the twelfth century - from 1107 to 1153. Mentioned in a colophon he copied or owned, and in a colophon of his son Shelomo. His brother, Ḥiyyā b. Yiṣḥaq, was the head judge of Fusṭāṭ, like their father.

name: Yehūda b. Ṣāliḥ b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Yehuda ha-Levi
description: Hebrew poet and author of The Kuzari, a philosophical defense of Judaism. Born in Toledo, died probably on the way to Palestine from Alexandria in 1141. Spent the last year or so of his life in Egypt where he composed numerous poems in honor of various individuals. Also a prolific author of liturgical poetry. Several of his autograph letters survived in the Geniza.

name: Yiṣḥaq b. Shemuʾel ha-Sefaradi
description:
He was one of two head judges in Fustat from the late 11th century until at least 1127 (together with Avraham b. Shemaʿya). He already appears as an important figure, "the great Rav," in a letter addressed to him by Evyatar Gaʾon, which bears the date 1091. 
Well over a hundred court deeds signed by him have survived in the Geniza. In addition, there are letters sent to him, and letters he wrote to others. 
He had two sons, Yehosef and Ḥiyya. Ḥiyya succeeded him as head judge and was also active for several decades. 
He wrote dozens of liturgical poems, a commentary on the Former Prophets, commentaries on Talmudic tractates, legal compositions on several subjects – which partially survived in the geniza and elsewhere. His compositions are also mentioned in several book lists found in the Geniza.
His signature as 'Sefaradi' shows that he, or his father, immigrated from the Muslim parts of the Iberian peninsula.

name: Yosef b. Yaʿaqov Ibn ʿAwkal
name_variants: Abū l-Faraj, Raʾs al-kull, Yūsuf b. Yaʿqūb b. ʿAwkal
description: Placeholder

name: Yūsuf b. Mūsā b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Zekharya b. Ḥayyim
description: Late 12th century (letter from 1172), traded in Palermo. Unconfirmed but might be a descendant of the 'Ammar family in 11th century Palermo.
